text: Delerue's theme from "Antoine and Colette" plays over an opening credit sequence consisting of a series of images Paris. Each shot is composition of the streets, landmarks and the minute details of this beautiful August afternoon The last shot begins wide on the Shakespeare Bookstore an closes in on a sign in the window announcing an event: "Jesse Wallace, young author of the acclaimed best-seller THIS TIME, Saturday, August 23." A brooding picture of Je is prominent. Over the image, we hear a French Journalist asking a question.
Do you consider the book to be autobiographical?
Inside this funky bookstore, JESSE, early 30's, is sittin casually with a few journalists and patrons.

isn't everything autobiographical, I mean we ail see the world from our own tiny keyhole. I always think of Thomas Wolfe - have you ever seen that little one page 'note to reader’ in the front of Look Homeward, Angel. Do you know what I'm talking about? Vague affirmatives. .

Anyway, He says how we are the sum of all the moments of our lives, that anybody who writes will use the clay of their lives, that you can't avoid that. I remember he says he can't imagine anything more autobiographical then Gulliver's Travels.

Over the next section of dialog, we see an approximately second series of shots from BEFORE SUNRISE that silently tell the story: boy meets girl on a train, boy and girl g to know one another, boy and girl kiss, get more intimate part at dawn.
When I look at my life, I have to admit I've never been around a bunch +e ee  Betore Sunrise Sequei Pank Pages 24/8/03 “he

of guns or violence, a helicopter crash, political intrigue. But my life, from my point of view, has been full of drama. And one of the most exciting things that's ever happened to me is actually connecting with another person and I thought if I could write a book that could capture that, make that connection valuable, that possibility...anyway that was the attempt. I don't know if that answers your question... He kh OF
"ll be more specific. Was there ever a young French woman on a train you met and spent an evening with?
See to me, that's not important.
So, that's a yes?

Okay, since this is the last stop of my book tour and I am in France, Yes. We're now near the end of the montage where Celine and Je say their good-byes at the train station and are soon traveling alone.
The book ends on an ambiguous note - we don't know. Do you think they get back together in six months like they promised each other?

I think how you answer that is a good test as to whether you ‘are a romantic or a cynic. * He looks at the journalists and points at each of them as speaks.  Before Sunrise Sequel Pink Pages 24/8/03 3.
You think they get back together, you don't, you hope they do but aren't sure.
But do YOU think they do? Did you in real life?
Well, in the words of my grandfather, to answer that would take the piss outta the whole thing. Still offscreen, the Bookstore Manager chimes in.
We have time for one last question.
We're now back inside.
What is your next book?
I've always wanted to write a book where the whole thing happens within the space of one pop song.
What song?

T don't know, haven't written it yet - "the Long and Winding Road" maybe... The story's about this guy living in Miami at his in-laws beach house, and he's totally depressed. His great dream was to be an adventurer, a lover, riding motorcycles through South America. But instead, he sitting at this marble table eating lobster, He's got a job, a beautiful . wife, all that he needs, but none of it matters - what he wants is to fight for meaning. Across the room, CELINE emerges from behind a row of book where she's been hiding and listening.
Happiness is in the doing, right? not getting what you want.
Before Sunrise Sequel Pink Pages 24/8403 4.

And just that second his five year- old daughter ‘jumps up on the table. He knows she shouldn't be there ~ she could get hurt. But she is dancing to this pop song in a summer dress. Celine is looking at him.

All of sudden he's 16 and his high- school sweetheart is dropping him off at home. They just lost their virginity and she loves him and the same song is playing on the car radio, and she climbs up dancing on the roof of the car. And now he's worried about her. She's beautiful with a facial expression just like his daughter. Maybe that's why he likes her. He knows he is not REMEMBERING this dance. He is there - he is there in both moments simultaneously. In fact he pulls away from a kiss with the girlfriend so as to not offend his daughter. Both moments are real, happening together. For @ moment all his life is foiding in and it's obvious to him that time is a lie... He looks up and sees Celine for the first time.
Its all happening all the time and inside every moment, is another, all happening simultaneously. He takes a beat, still looking at Celine, not sure what t do next.
Anyway, that's kinda the idea, anyway.

Our author needs to be going to the airport soon. I'd like to thank all ef you for coming over this afternoon, and especially like to thank Mr. Wallace for being with us. We hope to see you again with your next book. So everyone, please help yourselves to champagne and cookies.  Before Sunrise Sequel Pink Pages 24/8/03 5. There is polite applause and people start to disperse. Je looks back over to Celine - she gives a little wave. He gets the manager's attention.
(to Manager} How long 'till I have to leave here for the airport?
You should leave about 7:15 or so, 7:30 at the latest.
Okay... Jesse walks over to Celine.
Hi.
Hello. A slightly awkward double cheek kiss.
How are you?
Good, and you?
Great. You wanna get some coffee or something?
Didn't he just say you have a plane to catch?
I have a little time. Want to get out of here?
Okay.
Yes? Jesse goes back over to the manager.
I'll be back in thirty, forty-five minutes or so. We're just going to go get a cup of coffee.  Before Sunrise Sequel Pink Pages 24/8/03
Okay, but get your driver Phillipe's card so you'll have his cell phone. Call him if you're running late. SA.  Before Sunrise Sequel Green Pages 21/8/03 6.
We'll get your bags in the car so you won't be late to the airport.
Okay. Thanks for everything. As they start to exit the store, Jesse is detained briefl signing a book, getting the card from the driver, etc. Ce exits in front of him.
Outside the bookstore, Jesse puts his hands on Celine's shoulders and just looks at her.
I can't believe you're here!
I live here in Paris. Are you sure you don't have to stay? Aren't you supposed to talk to those people.
It's okay, they're sick of me - I spent the night here last night.
You did?
They have a loft upstairs. How are you? This is so weird.
I'm fine. It's good to see you.
Tt's good to see you too.
So you want to go to a cafe?
Sure.  Before Sunrise Sequel Pink Pages 24/87/03 7.
There's one a little further, that I like a lot. ®@ JESSE Alright. They start walking.
I thought I was going to totally lose it in there after I saw you. How'd you even know I was going to be here?
It's my favorite bookstore in Paris. You can sit down for hours, I love it - even if there's fleas.
I think a cat slept on my head last night.

I saw your picture on the calendar about a month ago and that you were going to be here. It's funny I read an article on your book and it sounded @ vaguely familiar, but I didn't put it all together until I saw the photo.
Did you have a chance to read it?
Yes. I was really surprised as you can imagine. {a beat) I had to read it twice, actually. Jesse just looks at her.
Comme ci comme ca?
No, I really like it - it's romantic. I usually don't like that but it's well written. Congratulations.
Thanks. e Celine suddenly stops and looks at Jesse.
Before Sunrise Sequel Green Pages 21/8/03
But. before we go anywhere I have to ask you, did you show up in Vienna that December?
Did you? TA.  Before Sunrise Sequel Pink Pages 24/8/03
I couldn't, but did you? I have to know. It's important to me.
(playful) Why, if you didn't?
Did you?
No.
Oh thank God you didn't. JESSE. Yeah, thank God you didn't either. If one of us would have been there alone, it would have sucked. They continue walking.
I know, I was so concerned with that. I've always felt horrible about not being there but I couldn't, my grandma died a few days before and she was buried that day, December 16th.
{almost relieved) She died? The one in Budapest?
How did you remember that?
I remember everything.
Oh, of course, it was in your book. Anyway, I was just about to fly to Vienna to meet you when we got the news about her, then of course I went to the funeral with my parents.
I'm so sorry to hear that.
Before Sunrise Sequel Pink Pages 24/8/03 9.

But you weren't there anyway. (suddenly suspicious) Wait, why weren't you there? If would have been there if I could have - I had made plans. You better have a good reason. They slow to a stop and just look at each other. She real he's. been lying.
Oh no! You were there, weren't you?
{down} Yeah,
Ahhhh! That's terrible! I'm so sorry. I'm laughing but Tf don't mean it. Did you hate me? You must have hated me. (a beat) Have you hated me all this time?
No.
Yes you have, but you can't hate me now.
No... I don't hate you. C'mon, no big deal. I flew over there, you blew the whole thing off, I gave up on love, and my life's been a big nose-dive since then, but hey, no big deal.
No!
I'm kidding.
I can't believe it. You must have felt really angry with me. I'm so sorry ~ I wanted to be there more than anything in the world. But you can't be angry anymore, I mean my grand-ma~-~
Before Sunrise Sequel Green Pages 21/8/03 10.
Honestly, I had a feeling something like that might have happened. I was bummed, but I was mostly just mad that we hadn't exchanged phone numbers or any information.
I know, that was so stupid - no way to get in touch, I didn't even know your last name.
I know! We had nothing to go on.
I was cursing... - If I could just reach him. .
I know, remember the reason we did that...we were both afraid if we started calling and writing it would slowly fade away.
It definitely wasn't a slow fade.
Sure wasn't.
Yes, we wanted to pick it up where we left off, which would have been a good idea if...
(butting in) If it'd just worked! Oh well.
So how long were you in Vienna?
Couple of days. .
Did you meet another girl?
Yeah, her name was Gretchen, she was awesome. The book's actually a composite of the two of you...  Before Sunrise Sequel Pink Pages 24/8/03
Really?!
No... I even went back to the train station and put up a sign that had the number to my hotel, just in case you had been delayed a half day or something... total dork.
Did you get any calls?
Just a couple of hookers looking for a gig. (a beat) Hey, it was awful, what do you want me to say?
Oh, that's so sad. I'm so sorry. They start walking again.
Then I just walked around for a while then eventually flew back home. I owed my dad two grand, who had warned me about French chicks.
What did he tell you about French women?
Nothing, lots of crap. He's never been with any French women. I don't think he's ever been east of the Mississippi.
Why didn't you put the six months later part in the book?
But I did!
Really?
I wrote a fictional version where you do show up.
You did? What happens?  Before Sunrise Sequel Pink Pages 24/8/03
Oh, we make love for like ten days straight... 1l~A.  Before Sunrise Sequel Pink Pages 24/8/03
That's interesting.
And then they find out more about each other and realize they don't really get along.
I like that.., It's more real.
My editor didn't feel that way.
Yes, everybody wants to believe in ilove. ft sells.
Yep.
But things are going well for you, right? {pause} Your book's a bestseller in the U.S.?
It's a tiny bestseller, but officially, yes. But hey, most people haven't read Moby Dick, so why the hell should they read my book?
I never read Moby Dick, but I liked your book, even though I thought you idealized our night a bit.
Hey, it's fiction.
i know, but I thought there wete times when you made me, I mean her, no, me, like sometimes she's was a bit... psychotic.
But you are a little like that.
i know... Whatil!
Just kidding. No really, where’d I do that?
Before Sunrise Sequel Pink Pages 24/8/03
Maybe it’s just me...It was so strange to be reading something knowing the character in the story is based on you. It's both flattering and disturbing at the same time.
Why was it disturbing?
I don't know, just -being part of someone's memory, suddenly seeing myself through your eyes. How long did it take you to write it?
On and off, 3 or 4 years.
It's a long time to be writing about one night.
Tell mea about it. I feel like I basically lived with you there for a while.
I'd always assumed you've forgotten me.
T had a pretty clear picture of you in my mind. I gotta tell you something - I've wanted to talk to you for so long...
Me too.
It's surreal, now I feel everything I say should be...
Yeah, and now we have what? twenty minutes and thirty seconds?
More than that, much more than that. I want to know about you. What are you up to? 13.  Before Sunrise Sequel Green Pages 21/8/03 13A.
Wheew. Where to start. I'm working for Green Cross, it’s an environmental organization.  Before Sunrise Sequel Pink Pages 24/8/03 14.
Wow. What are they all about?
We basically work on many different environment issues, from clean water to disarmament of chemical weapons you know, international laws that deal with the environment.
What do you do for them?
Different things. Last year I was in India for quite a while working on a water treatment plant.
Wow.
The cotton industry there is a major source of pollution.

I gotta say I admire the fact that it sounds like you are actually DOING something. Most people, myself included, just bitch about everything: how America's consuming all the world's resources, we're creating sweat shops in China, SUVs suck global warming...
I'm relived to hear you're not one of those Freedom Fry kind of Americans.
Nah. But I gotta say, I think that's S80 cool what you're doing. How'd you get into that?

When I.came out of political science I thought I'd be working for the government, and I did for a short while and then I got tired of having conversations with friends about how the world was falling to pieces.
Before Sunrise Sequel Green Pages 21/8/03 14K.
I realized that the only thing I wanted to do was to look at things that really can be fixed and try to e@ fix them.  Before Sunrise Sequel He laughs.
hey bo c Pink Pages 24/8/03 15.
I gotta say, that's awesome. I always figured you'd be doing something cool like that.
Thanks. I'm lucky to have a job I really like.
You know, I actually alternate in thinking that everything is irrevocably screwed up, and actually feeling things in a general might be getting better.
Better! How could “you possibly think that?
I know it sounds weird, but I think there are things to be optimistic about.
(interrupting) Okay, I know your book is selling, but what are you talking about - the world's a mess right now.

rom a western point of view things are getting a bit better - we're moving all our industry to developing nations to get cheap labor free from any environmental laws. The weapons industry is out of control, five million die every year due to preventable water diseases. So how is the world getting better? I'm not getting angry, but really I want to know?
I know there are a lot of serious problems - I don't have one publisher in the entire Asian market. laugh, approaching the cafe.
Before Sunrise Sequel Green Pages 21/8/03 15A.
But I think there's more awareness out there.  é Before Sunrise Sequel Green Pages 21/8/03 16.

It might be getting better because people like you are informed and educated and speaking out and as the world's consciousness and education vises - things like women's issues, racial rights, sexual rights, children's rights...
I know.

I mean the very notion of conservation and environmental issues - all that weren't even in the vocabulary until fairly recently - those are becoming the norm and will eventually be what's expected all over the world.
IT agree with what you are saying but it's dangerous. An imperialist country can use that kind of thinking to justify their economic greed. Human rights is the only issue I...
They walk in and eventually seat themselves.
Any particular imperialist country you got in mind there, Frency?
No, not really. Is it okay if we sit here?

Perfect. But what I'm really saying is the world might be evolving like a person evolves. ME for example... Am I improving? Am I getting worse? When I was younger I was healthier but I was racked with insecurity- Now I'm older my problems are deeper, but I'm more equipped to handle them.
What are your problems? Long Pause.
Before Sunrise Sequel Pink Pages 24/8/03
Right now, I don"t feel like I have any - just damn happy to be here.
Me too. How long have you been in Paris?
Got in last night. I've done ten cities in twelve days - I'm so glad it's over. I'm so sick of being a huckster The waitress comes over to the table.
Bonjour. Vous dinner?
What do you want?
Just a coffee.
Non, un cafe, et une orange pressee avec des glacons,.
I love the coffee over here so much more than in the U.S.
I couldn't even drink coffee when I was living over there.
You lived in the U.S.? When?
From '96 through '99. I was studying at NYU.
Don't tell me that!
What?
Ch wow - that’s weird. I've been in New York since '98. That's wild - we were both there at the same time. 17.  Before Sunrise Sequel Green Pages 21/8/03 18.

That is weird. You know, it actually crossed my mind, if I might run into you there, but the odds are so slim, e you know? I had no idea even what town you were living in. Weren't you somewhere in Texas?
I was for a long time but, I had to get out there. I figured it was time for me to be in New York. What made you come back here?
IT had finished my master's, for one, but I was starting to get paranoid. The stuff in the medias all the time - murders, gang violence, serial killers.
i know.
I was living in terror. The final straw was one night I heard some noise on my fire escape, I called 911 and the cops came...
Like three hours later.

After I'd been raped and killed about ten times. It was a man and a woman officer. I was describing to them what I had heard when the woman had to run downstairs to move the police car. I was alone with the male cop, and right away he asked me if I had agun. I said no and he told me I'd better think about getting one - this was America, not France. I told him I didn't know how to shoot . a gun and that I wasn't interested in firearms. That is when he pulled out his gun and said to me... {cop voice) "One day you're going to have something like this in your face, and if you want to live a long life, you're going to have to choose between  Before Sunrise Sequel Pink Pages 24/8/03

you or them." They left and the next morning, I actually called for an application to get a gun. Me, a @ gun! But then I started thinking that something was wrong, the way that cop had pulled his gun.
Yeah, sure.
So I canceled my demand for a gun and instead I called the police station and tried to complain about this cop's behavior.
What happened with that?
It was so much paper work and with my shitty student visa, so I gave up and forgot about the whole thing. Well, actually no, I never forgot.
Obviously. @ Coffee arrives.
But still, I wouldn't mind being back there - there's a lot of things I miss about the U.S.
Like what?
The overall good mood people have even if it can be bullshit. Like “hey, how you doing? Great! How YOU doin? Great! Have a great day." Parisians are so grumpy. Have you noticed?
Really? Everyone around here seems pretty happy to me.
They're not happy. Maybe I just mean the French men, they drive me @ nuts.
Before Sunrise Sequel Pink Pages
What about them? 24/8/03 19A.  Before Sunrise Sequel Green Pages 21/8/03
You know, French guys like wine, and food, they're fun, maybe it's just me, bad luck, but there not that..-
What? 19B.  Before Sunrise Sequel Pink Pages 24/8/03 20.
What's the word... horny.
In that regard, I'm proud to be an ‘merican.
And you should be ~ in that regard only. Have you ever spent any time in Eastern Europe?
No.
I remember as a teenager I went to Warsaw when it was still a strict communist regime, which I don't approve of at all.
Sure you don't.

I don't at all, really. But something about being there after a while was very interesting, I found. After a couple of weeks something changed in me. The city was quite gloomy and gray but after a while my brain seemed Clearer. I was writing a lot more in my journal, ideas I had never thought of before.
Communist ideas?
Shut up! I'm not a communist.
I know. Go ahead, sorry.

It took me a while to figure out why, why I felt so different. And then, one day as I was walking throvgh the Jewish cemetery, I don't know why but it occurred to me there, i realized I had just spent the past couple of weeks away from most of my habits. The TV was in a language I didn't understand and there was nothing to buy, no advertisements anywhere.
Before Sunrise Sequel Pink Pages 24/8/03 20A.
So all I had been doing for three weeks was walk around, write, think. My brain felt like it was at rest, free from the consuming frenzy and 1 have to say it was almost like a natural high.
Before Sunrise Sequel Green Pages 21/8/03 20B.
I was so peaceful inside, no strange urges to be somewhere else, to shop.  Before Sunrise Sequel Pink Pages 24/8/03 21.
Maybe it could have seemed like boredom at first but it quickly it became very soulful.
Can you believe it was nine years ago we were walking around Vienna?
No, that's impossible.
Feels like two months ago... but dune of "94.
De I look any different?
Mommm. Your hair was down back then, can you... She undoes her hair. Jesse keeps looking at her.
Little skinnier I think.
Was I fat before?
No, no.
You thought I was a fatty. You wrote a book about a fat girl. They both laugh.
No seriously - you look beautiful. Do I look any different?
Before Sunrise Sequel Pink Pages 24/8/03
No... you have this little line here. She points to the wrinkle between his eyebrows.
I know, I know.
Like a scar.
A scar? Like a gunshot wound?
No, I like it. I had a terrible nightmare the other day. I was having an awful dream that I was 32, then i woke up and I was 23, relieved, and then I woke up for real and I was 32.
Aw shit, it happens.
Time gets faster and faster. Apparently it's because we don't renew our synapses after 20, so it's all pretty much downhill from then on.
On the other hand, I like getting older. Life feels more immediate - You can appreciate it more.
Oh I know. I actually like it too.
I was once a drummer in a band.
You were?

And we were pretty good too. But the lead singer was so obsessed with us getting signed. We spent all our time thinking about getting bigger gigs- all about the future. And now the band doesn't even exist anymore. 22.  Before Sunrise Sequel Green Pages 21/8/03 22A.
But looking back at those shows we did, even rehersing, it was so much fun.  Before Sunrise Sequel Pink Pages 24/8/03
I think now I'd be able to enjoy every minute of it.
Well, you've got your book published and you're travelling ali over the They laugh. world with it... are you enjoying it?
Not really.
You know in my field, I see some people that come into it like with big idealist visions, of becoming the new leaders that will create a better world, they enjoy the goal but not the process.
Right .

But the reality of it is that the true work of improving things is in the little achievements of the day, and that's what you need to enjoy to stay in that field. For example I worked for an organization that helped villages in Mexico and their concerns was how to get the pencils sent to the kids in those little country schools, it was not about discussing big revolutionary ideas about a better world - it was about pencils. I see the people that do the real work, and what in a way is really sad is that the people that are often the most giving, hard working and capable of making this world better don’t really have the ambition and ego to be a leader, they don't see any interest in the rewards, they don’t care if their name ever appear in the press, they actually enjoy the process of helping others, they are truly in the moment.
Yeah, that's such a struggle.
toh OF
Before Sunrise Sequel Pink Pages 24/8/03 23A.

It seems like we're designed to be slightly dis-contented with everything. Always trying to better @ our situation. You satisfy one desire and it just agitates another. But then I think, well, desire is the fuel of life. Do you think it's true that we'd never be unhappy if we never wanted anything?
Before Sunrise Sequel Green Pages 21/8/03 24.
I don't know actually. Not wanting anything... Isn't it a symptom of depression? it's very human to desire.
That's what all those Buddhist cats say, right, liberate yourself from desire and you will find you already have everything you need.

But I feel human when I want something more than just basic survival needs. Wanting, whether it's intimacy with another person or a new pair of shoes is kind of beautiful. I like that we have ever-renewing desires.

Yeah... I guess it's just entitlement that brings all the pain. Whenever you feel you deserve that pair of shoes, that your desires SHOULD be met. It's all right to have wants and needs as long as you don't get angry when they're not realized. Life is hard, it's supposed to be, if we didn't suffer we would never learn a thing.
So what, are you like a Buddhist or something?
No.
Why not?
i don't know, it's probably like when I go to a museum I don't get - the headphones with the guided tour.  Before Sunrise Sequel Pink Pages 24/8/03
I know. I decided a long time ago that I wanted be open to everything, but not buy into any one belief system.
I like that. I went to this Trappist monastery @ couple years ago.
Trappist?
Catholic, Cistertian.
Why did you go there?
I don't know, I'd been doing a bunch of reading, thought it'd be cool. Have you ever spent time with any monks or nuns?
Not my style.

I was shocked - I expected them to be ail glowering and stern but they weren't - they were quick to laugh and really easy to be around, very attuned to everything. They're not trying to hustle anybody, they're not trying to accomplish anything, they are trying to live and die in peace and be close with God or whatever part of them they feel is eternal - it's so refreshing to be around. You realize that the bulk of people that you meet are trying to get somewhere better, make a little more jack, get a little more respect, have more people admire them... it's exhausting.
No kidding.
And it's exhausting to be one of those people yourself. 25.  Before Sunrise Sequel Pink Pages 24/8/03 26.
I'm at a monastery, greedy to be a little more spiritual, "I want to be a better person." You can't escape.

I had a boyfriend many years ago that wanted to be a Buddist and he went to Asia to visit several monasteries. He was very good looking and everytime he went to one of those monasteries a monk offered to suck his cock. They laugh. He laughs.
Well, it all comes down to that, doesn't it? That's why I think I really admire what you're doing.
You mean sucking cock?
No. I'm just saying it sounds like you're not detached from the world. You're putting your life and passion into tangible action,
I'm just doing my best.
You know something?
What?
I'm going to be sitting down on a plane and in airports for the next eight hours or something. Would you - mind walking around with me a little bit?
Are you inviting me?
Before Sunrise Sequel Pink Pages 24/8/03 27.
Yes, let's go. They stand up. He glances at the bill and takes out a fiv Euro note.
Is this enough? Even for a tip?
Yep. They start walking out.
Anywhere to walk to around here?
t's sales day today.
What's that?
It's when everything is on sale in Paris. Twice a year.
Then let's go shopping.
No, no, no, I don't want to inflict that on you - it's madness. Let's go up to the garden path - it's a nice way back.
That sounds better than shopping, actually, not that I wasn't up for doing anything you wanted.
They are walking, approaching the garden path.
Sometimes, I can get high on just looking and trying on things, I don't even need to buy.
A therapist would tell you it's all good.
Are you ever in therapy? +o Ot  Before Sunrise Sequel Pink Pages 24/8/03 278.
Does it seem like I’m in therapy?  Before Sunrise Sequel Pink Pages 24/8/03
t don't know - has it helped your sex problems?
(wide eyed) Sex problems?
No, I'm kidding.
They continue their walk/talk.
No, no, tell me the truth. Did we have problems that night?
I was kidding. We didn't even have sex anyway.
What? That's a joke, right?
No, we didn't. That was the whole thing.
Of course we did.
But we didn't. You didn't have a condom and I never have sex without one, especially if it was a one night thing. I'm extremely paranoid about my health.
I'm finding this very scary that you don't remember what happened.
You know what, I didn't write an entire book, but I kept a journal and I wrote the whole night in it. That's what I meant by you idealizing the night.  Before Sunrise Sequel Green Pages 21/8/03 29.
(a bit louder) I even remember the brand of condom I used.
That's disgusting. Walking by are an older couple with three kids. They look back, a bit shocked.
No it isn't.
Alright, when I get home, T'il check my journal from '94, but I know I'm right. . {a beat} Wait a minute. Was it in the cemetery?
Noooc. We visited the cemetery during the day. It was in a4 park, very late at night.
Wait a minute.
Was it that forgettable? You don't remember, in the park?
Wait a minute, I think you might be right.
You're messing with me.
Sorry, no you're right. It's strange sometimes it's like I put things in drawers inside my head and forget about it.  Before Sunrise Sequel Pink Pages 24/8/03 30.
I guess it is less painful to put certain things away than to live with it.
